channel.description: All Product Hunt podcast β submissions wrapped in one podcast updated hourly

item.title: Does Not Compute - Episode 1: There's Always Paypal
item.description: How asking questions is the best way to learn how to code.
item.dc:creator: Unknown
item.itunes:author: Unknown
item.itunes:subtitle: How asking questions is the best way to learn how to code.
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 49 | How asking questions is the best way to learn how to code.

Comments

Josh Dunsterville: Yet another great podcast from the Spec Network!

Bryn Jackson: The best part of creating Spec has been that we can enable talented people to help other designers and developers level up without having to buy their own equipment, do all their own editing, or sell their own sponsorships to make the shows viable. Sean and Paul are crazy talented and this show is great, so I'm absolutely stoked to have them on the network.

Michael Schultz: Super excited about this show. Sean and Paul are two smart programmers and they tend to have a very thoughtful, well-rounded advice on just about every topic.

item.title: Angel Insights - Modwenna Rees-Mogg, co-Founder @ CrowdRating
item.description: Modwenna chats about what makes a great investor.
item.dc:creator: Harry Stebbings
item.itunes:author: Harry Stebbings
item.itunes:subtitle: Modwenna chats about what makes a great investor.
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 20 | Modwenna chats about what makes a great investor.

Comments

tom britton: This is an amazing episode Harry, Modwenna has such a diverse background which she draws on to shape her intelligent approach to Angel investing.

Harry Stebbings: Modwenna Rees Mogg (@modwenna) is an experienced corporate financier turned entrepreneur, as the founder of www.angelnews.co.uk, the leading private investor news service with the goal of improving transparency and accountability in the early stage investment market to enable it to grow and create win:win situations for all concerned. Modwenna has also recently Co-Founded CrowdRating, the ratings agency for equity crowdfunding. In today’ episode we delve into why now is the best time to be an angel investor, what separates a great angel from a good angel and how to utilize your investing network for maximum dealflow.

For your chance to win a signed copy of the legendary Venture Deals by Brad Feld (@bfeld) all you have to do is click the click to tweet: http://ctt.ec/e0zkG

In Today’s Episode You Will Learn:

1.) How did Modwenna get into the investing world?
2.) Why is now the best time to be an angel investor and what has changed over the last few years that has made this happen?
3.) What does Modwenna think separates the incredible angel from the less useful investor?
4.) What does Modwenna think of the syndicated model of angel investing? Has Modwenna seen a rise in the amount of angel due to crowdfunding platforms increasing accessibility?
5.) If a startup has more than one angel on the cap sheet, who should be the lead investor? What are the characteristics of a great lead investor?
6.) Modwenna tells us a little about Crowdrating, what the site does and how CrowdRating (http://www.crowdrating.co.uk) assesses whether a project is a solid investment or not?

Items Mentioned In Today’s Show:
Modwenna’s Fave Investing Resource: CB Insights (https://www.cbinsights.com)

item.title: The Wolf Den - 90: Ryan Hoover of Product Hunt
item.description: Ryan joins Adam Sachs to talk about the podcast industry
item.dc:creator: Ryan Hoover, Adam Sachs
item.itunes:author: Ryan Hoover, Adam Sachs
item.itunes:subtitle: Ryan joins Adam Sachs to talk about the podcast industry
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 17 | Ryan joins Adam Sachs to talk about the podcast industry

Comments

Adam Sachs: It was really fun to have @rrhoover on. I'm excited about the effect that Product Hunt can have on building and engaging podcast fan communities. @kkliman @alexcartaz I really appreciate the support. Also, feedback is welcome!

Kevin Kliman: So many good insights from @arsachs conversations, and before that the original company founder in the early episodes. Every episode has great takeaways about the industry.

Ryan Hoover: Thanks for having me, @arsachs. We talked a bit about podcast discovery and opportunity to grow communities around podcasts. I'm curious to hear from others. Where do you discover new podcasts? Do you share them on Twitter, FB, or more niche podcast-focused forums?

Alex Carter: The Wolf Den is now one of my "must listen to every episode" podcasts. Great for keeping a pulse on the podcast meta. @jsneedles here's another one of the Hoover collection =)

Lyle McKeany: I'm glad they replayed this old episode since it aired before I had heard of 99pi. Great episode!

Tyler Swartz: From their website: 99% Invisible is honored to accept a 2015 Third Coast International Audio Festival award for Structural Integrity, a story of architectural engineering gone wrong, and then covertly made right.

item.title: Reactive - 12: Focus on the things that are cool
item.description: Twitter layoffs, npm Orgs, how to keep up.
item.dc:creator: kahlil ✰, Henning Glatter-Götz
item.itunes:author: kahlil ✰, Henning Glatter-Götz
item.itunes:subtitle: Twitter layoffs, npm Orgs, how to keep up.
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 13 | Twitter layoffs, npm Orgs, how to keep up.

Comments

Harry Stebbings: @kahliltweets would love to hear what you think of @twentyminutevc we cover all things VC, startups, investments and of course twitter!

Harry Stebbings: Really enjoyed this episode @kahliltweets definitely subscribing for the future. Great to hear your thoughts on Twitter for the older generation. Would love to hear what you think will happen with Jack Dorsey being CEO of 2 publicly traded companies, with Square filing for IPO!

Henning Glatter-Götz: This was a fun one to record

kahlil ✰: Kahlil gave a talk on Observables. How do you keep up with technology? Twitter lays off a large number of employees. Twitter is for old people. Project management and software estimating is hard. The state of npm Orgs. Photoshop is dead and why Kahlil is going to keep his latest twitter handle for all times.

Timeline

00:00:00 Pre show, or not?
00:05:56 Intro
00:06:20 Kahlil's talk about Observables
00:18:40 Keeping up
00:29:37 Twitter layoffs
00:32:57 Twitter is for old people
00:37:26 Live coding
00:41:27 Frontend Masters Ember.js Workshop
00:43:33 Project management and software estimation
00:50:11 npm Orgs
00:56:35 New Slack members
00:58:36 Raquel's Slack Channel challenge
01:00:21 JSConf EU Impressions
01:01:03 Photoshop is dead
01:02:13 Computer Show
01:04:28 Why @kahliltweets?

kahlil ✰: @harrystebbings I'll have a listen and let you know

kahlil ✰: @harrystebbings hey thanks, glad you liked it and thanks for subscribing! I was actually thinking about that during the episode too. It'll be interesting to see how Jack does. I read the article by Ev where he detailed how they weighed all other options and that they truly truly believe that Jack can do both. What I like is that he is a product guy! I hope he can find the balance between satisfying shareholders and keeping Twitter cool for people like us 😉

item.title: Full Stack Radio - 27: Ben Orenstein
item.description: Talk about Outside-in TDD, Dependency Injection and Rails
item.dc:creator: Ben Orenstein, Adam Wathan
item.itunes:author: Ben Orenstein, Adam Wathan
item.itunes:subtitle: Talk about Outside-in TDD, Dependency Injection and Rails
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 11 | Talk about Outside-in TDD, Dependency Injection and Rails

Comments

Radoslav Stankov: This reminded my about a lot of stuff I took for granted now days - like Outside in development, TDD, common Rails mistakes.

At the very end the latest Corley Haines book - "Understanding the 4 Rules of Simple Design" gets mentioned. They mentioned - "Don't use `new`, create a factory method describing the instance" tip. I'm doing quite often, but had forgotten from where I had picked it up.

item.title: Gentlemans Dub Club FM: Episode 1
item.description: 1st in the series - a mix of Reggae, Ska, Dub & mashup style
item.dc:creator: Unknown
item.itunes:author: Unknown
item.itunes:subtitle: 1st in the series - a mix of Reggae, Ska, Dub & mashup style
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 6 | 1st in the series - a mix of Reggae, Ska, Dub & mashup style

Comments

Ben Tossell: This is the first in the series of @Gentlemansdub podcast series.

These guys are from the UK and I've seen them multiple times, notably in Nottingham and Glastonbury Festival: they actually commented on my FB post about Glastonbury calling me an idiot (in good spirit) because me and my buddy were punching ourselves in the head going mad over the tunes.

My favourite song of all time is covered (by Kiko Bun) in this podcast if you listen at 11 Minutes.

Enjoy!

Also this is my favourite song from @Gentlemansdub : https://soundcloud.com/gentlemans-dub-club/gentlemans-sleng-ft-bongo-chilli

item.title: The Pitch - 8: Ironclad
item.description: The pitch from Ironclad, YC backed legal automation startup
item.dc:creator: Sheel Mohnot, Michael Cardamone, Josh Muccio, Jason Boehmig, Sophie Masure, Jacob Bendicksen, Sofia Pietrella
item.itunes:author: Sheel Mohnot, Michael Cardamone, Josh Muccio, Jason Boehmig, Sophie Masure, Jacob Bendicksen, Sofia Pietrella
item.itunes:subtitle: The pitch from Ironclad, YC backed legal automation startup
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 29 | The pitch from Ironclad, YC backed legal automation startup

Comments

Ryan Hoover: Haha, @joshmuccio beat me to this hunt by 2 minutes. I listened to the show this morning.

I can definitely empathize with the pain of setting up, distributing, and managing legal docs. Clerky is a useful tool used by most YC companies but it only streamlines a subset of the paperwork (right now).

P.S. Here's Ironclad's launch on Product Hunt from a few months ago.

Josh Muccio: Hey PH family! Today we’re featuring Ironclad (http://producthunt.com/tech/ironclad), an automated assistant that handles legal paperwork. They are fresh out of Y Combinator and we met with founder Jason Boehmig in San Francisco.

Listen as Jason pitches to...

Michael Cardamone, managing director at Acceleprise, the SaaS incubator.

Mar Hershenson, managing partner of Pejman Mar Ventures, where they invest in very early stage tech startups.

Neil Devani, investor and GC at Rothenberg Ventures, where they invest in early stage companies with a focus on frontier technologies.

Hope you like it... 😁

Josh Muccio: Well that's cool. Honored to be on your playlist @rrhoover

I'll let you hunt the next one 😜

You must like short podcasts?

Ryan Hoover: @joshmuccio I actually like long podcasts too. This Week in Tech and This Week in Startups are 1.5+ hours and I'm a regular listener. 😊

Sheel Mohnot: @rrhoover We need to get you as a guest! What kind of startups would you like to be on the panel for?

Ryan Hoover: @pitdesi that would be really fun! I'm down for anything, but perhaps something consumer-focused. That'll be more fun. I'm at ryan at producthunt.com.

Josh Muccio: @rrhoover @pitdesi great idea! We're also open to startup recommendations. So when you run into an amazing consumer-focused startup let us know.

item.title: Descriptive - 22: with Ashley Williams
item.description: Building abstractions that aren't ahistorical
item.dc:creator: kahlil ✰, Henning Glatter-Götz
item.itunes:author: kahlil ✰, Henning Glatter-Götz
item.itunes:subtitle: Building abstractions that aren't ahistorical
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 3 | Building abstractions that aren't ahistorical

Comments

kahlil ✰: @kahliltweets and @hglattergotz talk to @ag_dubs about her introduction to computers and programming with Logo and HyperCard. Ashley explains how her degrees in philosophy and neuroscience help her reason about program architecture and where her interest in teaching comes from. She becomes the lead instructor at Flatiron School after being rejected as a student, which leads to many different teaching and speaking engagements. Before taking a position at npm, Inc. she also worked at Mozilla and Bocoup.

Highlights

[00:00:00] Kahlil welcomes Ashley Williams to the show
[00:00:58] Logo
[00:01:42] HyperCard
[00:06:35] Philosophy and Neuroscience
[00:22:02] Where @ag_dubs comes from
[00:23:46] Teaching
[00:35:24] From rejected student to lead instructor
[00:42:27] NYC Web Development Fellowship
[00:49:44] bocoup
[00:51:19] endpoints
[00:59:32] APIs and API driven development
[01:01:56] Ashley's personal website
[01:07:26] Mozilla
[01:08:56] Low Cost Education
[01:12:02] Conference Talks
[01:14:56] npm, Inc.
[01:25:18] Writing documentation
[01:34:33] Picks

item.title: The Tim Ferriss Show - Jane McGonigal on getting more done
item.description: Can games be harnessed to make our lives better?
item.dc:creator: Jane McGonigal
item.itunes:author: Jane McGonigal
item.itunes:subtitle: Can games be harnessed to make our lives better?
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 21 | Can games be harnessed to make our lives better?

Comments

Joe Filcik: Cool episode. Over the past couple months I've heard Jane McGonigal interviewed on several podcasts, on her book tour. It's interesting how different the various interviews are. The interviewer impacts the discussion a lot (btw - same is true for Stanley Mcchrystal on both Tim's show and the Linkedin Speakers series). Makes me think that pivoting on Guests or the People in the episode could become a really interesting pivot for Product Hunt Podcasts. @AlexCartaz, have you thought about that? I guess makers give you that pivot, as long as Guests get added as makers.

Harry Stebbings: I found this so inspiring to hear @avantgame talk about the amazing struggle she faced after hitting her head. Absolutely amazing lady and so inspiring. Used her TED video before my exams to make nerves my friend! @tferriss awesome as always!

item.title: Hopes & Pains – Michael Sacca
item.description: Eight minutes of honesty on worry, balance, and purpose.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Knoll
item.itunes:author: Thomas Knoll
item.itunes:subtitle: Eight minutes of honesty on worry, balance, and purpose.
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 14 | Eight minutes of honesty on worry, balance, and purpose.

Comments

Chris Conrey: As a guest on one of these episodes it's nice to have others comment on your Hopes and Pains as well as seeing others who are in the same boat and have the same things in their heads. Being "not alone" is a powerful boost.

Josiah Austin Gulden: Loving the simplicity and honesty of @thomasknoll's new podcast "Hopes & Pains". This episode features PH OG @michaelsacca, who shares his thoughts on three things that most entrepreneurs and makers are all too familiar with: the pervasiveness of worry, the elusiveness of balance, and a burning desire to make a meaningful impact. Eight minutes well spent!

Thomas Knoll: @conrey an honor to have you sir! The not-being-alone-ness is the most exciting part of this whole project for me.

Thomas Knoll: @jgulden Thank you for the kind words. This has been an eye opening experience to say the least.

item.title: Another Round - Madam Secretary, what's good?
item.description: Heben and Tracy chat with Hillary Clinton
item.dc:creator: Unknown
item.itunes:author: Unknown
item.itunes:subtitle: Heben and Tracy chat with Hillary Clinton
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 14 | Heben and Tracy chat with Hillary Clinton

Comments

SmallEyez: really really feelin the vibes and dialogue. funny. refreshing and relevant!!! more of this diversity is needed in the podcast world. were out here just need that light shone!! very powerful moments captured with possibly the future president of america!

Alex Carter: This is an amazing chat with Hillary. Heben and Tracy talk about policy, sexism on the Hill, and also don't pull any punches when asking Hillary hard questions, like:

"A lot of people feel like you and your husband, former president Bill Clinton, are implicit in the policies that were passed in the 90's. The tough on crime initiative, the 3 strikes rule. I feel like what a lot of black people are looking for is for you and your husband to shoulder some responsibility... do you ever look at the state of Black America, regardless of what your intentions were... and say 'wow we really fucked this up for black people'?"

item.title: Revision Path - 100: Sarah Huny Young
item.description: A deep conversation with creative director Sarah Huny Young
item.dc:creator: Unknown
item.itunes:author: Unknown
item.itunes:subtitle: A deep conversation with creative director Sarah Huny Young
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 6 | A deep conversation with creative director Sarah Huny Young

Comments

Maurice Cherry: For Revision Path’s 100th interview, I had the opportunity to talk with design powerhouse Sarah Huny Young. Huny’s portfolio speaks for itself, and she’s done next-level design work for big entertainment brands like VIBE Magazine and BET. Currently, she’s the founder of Supreme Clientele, a design agency in Pittsburgh, PA that has done work for award-winning websites like VSB, Soulbounce, The Curvy Fashionista, and the Women’s Freedom Conference.

item.title: EconTalk - Pete Boettke on Katrina, ten years after
item.description: Lessons learned from Katrina recovery after 10 yrs of study
item.dc:creator: Unknown
item.itunes:author: Unknown
item.itunes:subtitle: Lessons learned from Katrina recovery after 10 yrs of study
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 2 | Lessons learned from Katrina recovery after 10 yrs of study

Comments

Joe Filcik: Russ here does a followup interview with Prof. Pete Boettke whose been leading a team studying the on-the-ground reality of Hurricane Katrina recovery on the Gulf coast. There's some great stories of recovery and interesting discussion of how economic studies are done.

Couple interesting notes:
- Pete setup teams focused on looking at recovery from 3 perspectives - Government, Private Sector and "Civil Society" (e.g. churches, clubs, schools, other non-profits)

- New Orleans suffered in recovery from not allowing "Permissionless Innovation" and from preventing skilled laborers, who could rebuild homes, from using their licenses in New Orleans. Feels a bit like Uber & AirBnB's struggles with regulations.

-Pete articulates an interesting model for how structural changes happen in the economy (see picture) - Ideas legitimate institutions (ex. Private Property - The fact that people believe in the idea, decreases the cost of enforcement and so helps create it)
-> Institutions structure intensives and control flow of information and feedback
-> This Generates economics performance
-> We evaluate the outcome based on Ideas about "the good life" and "human flourishing" feedback into which ideas have traction.

Joe Filcik: @jfilcik Link to iTunes: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/econtalk/id135066958?mt=2&i=354625512

item.title: The Mating Grounds - Ep. 3, Helping Joe
item.description: Joe makes a funny mistake on his first Tinder date
item.dc:creator: Unknown
item.itunes:author: Unknown
item.itunes:subtitle: Joe makes a funny mistake on his first Tinder date
item.itunes:summary:
▲ 1 | Joe makes a funny mistake on his first Tinder date

Comments

Joe Antenucci: Every week @tuckermax @charliehoehn and @nilsAparker sit down with me to help with my problems meeting and dating women. I am a 26 year old ginger. I'm a smart, nice, normal guy that doesn't do well with women and just moved to Austin, Texas. They go over my issues, insecurities, and anxieties about sex & dating and they help solve them so I can reach my goals and live a happy life.

Some highlights from this episode:
-I made a critical but hilarious mistake on one first date. It was obvious to Charlie and Tucker what happened, but I was oblivious to it at the time.
-"Joe is exceedingly average. This is a normal dude, and most dudes out there are doing the same sorts of [stupid] things… totally oblivious. And girls are like, ‘What the fuck is going on?’”
-There could be a million reasons why she doesn't show up or cancels a date, don't take it personally.
-With each date, you get more experience and you get it really cheap. You will be better off for next time. Just keep showing up. You will get better.
-The first thing to do on the first date is make her feel comfortable and safe. Just do what’s normal, simple, and easy at the beginning.
-Most guys don’t know how to act natural because they don’t get enough reps.
-The number and strength of relationships has huge health implications, even for things like testosterone.
